title: Fast and easy hydraulic troubleshooting with this secret weapon!

comments.text:
I wish I would have seen this a couple weeks ago when I was helping a 
friend troubleshoot a hydraulic problem on a Bobcat.﻿

comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
Good video. Thank you.

Now the bad news. Your valve will fail again.

A little RDFA. The valve failed because of dirt. Where'd it come from. Just 
look at your work area.

Hydrulic work should be do in a very clean area (dare I say clean room?) . 

Good video.﻿
comments.author: James Taylor

comments.text: You are so right. It amazes me how hard that concept is get across.
comments.author: James Taylor

comments.text:
+James Taylor Cheers James! Well said. I always have time to do it right 
the second time, eh? :)
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
Actually I have over 50 years in the field, both military and industrial. I 
agree that actual conditions in the field are actually worse than what you 
showed. But that doesn't change the fact that it's not the way it should be 
and is causing many repeat failures. The clearances in hydraulic components 
are such that even very small particles can cause damage.
I didn't mean to imply you were working wrong, just that cleanness is very 
important.
comments.author: James Taylor

comments.text:
+James Taylor I'm guessing you've never worked in the field? Of course it 
will fail again, that's what gear does.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:

comments.author: Shane Quinn

comments.text:
would this heat gun tell me if i have an internal blockage on one of the 
hydraulic hoses on my skidder ??? in other words , would a restriction in a 
hydraulic line cause heat where it is blocked or only at the pump ???﻿
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
Im going to drain the oil cooler and check the hoses and flow from the pump 
to cooler tomorrow. but both lines too and from cooler are hot as well.
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
Ill start it up and let it idle for a bit, like 15 mins and you cannot 
touch the pump or priority valve its so hot, i could see it being hot after 
working it hard but not after 15 mins of idling 
It does have a steering wheel. is there a way i can check the steering 
valve ??
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
skidder have orbitrol valve (steering wheel) or just a lever for 
articulating? orbitrol valves often wear out and bypass severely before 
anybody notices because there is a priority valve that makes sure brakes 
and steering get whatever they need regardless of leakage. That valve would 
be nice a toasty if there is a problem.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: I don't know what else to check or clean, the steering valve maybe
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
you are the first guy with a hydraulics question that actually said thank 
you!
You are welcome. I'd be surprised if it was a hose giving you grief I've 
only seen the rubber flat routine twice in as many decades...
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: thanks for the reply btw
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
Ive been down for a month now trying to figure out why my hydraulics 
overheat, the pumps been looked at by the dealer and they said its good, 
they figure its a collapsed line, first they said the pressure relief valve 
but i changed that and still overheats. I got the pump head resurfaced 
because of cavitation and will reinstall it monday morning.
comments.author: barniescamp

comments.text:
Maybe. It'll cause heat where it's restricted, won't cause any heat in the 
line if it's fully blocked. If the hose is a couple degrees hotter than 
everything else then you got a problem.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
Sir its a complete mess :), why wont the upstream devices of pump be on

comments.author: Mon257

comments.text:
+arduinoversusevil yes considering $$$ those components i see are non 
mountable on blocks. I work on a meltshop hence components are expensive 
like rexroth, parkers unlike those i see on your set up. But its better to 
buy good product a its tested on long run and can save breakdowns and cut 
cost on maintenance.
comments.author: Mon257

comments.text:
+arduinoversusevil yes with manifolds/ block you could place in more of the 
components such as dc valves, RV, flow controls in one single robust 
location and neat. Drilling only the pressure, return and working ports it 
could be a safe and good allocation of the components considering safe and 
cut cost on hoses and fittings. If any breakdown we could only remove the 
components that is heat producing like RV - pilot or direct operated. After 
set up of blocks and components installed properly only the working ports 
(A&B) to be installed on hydro motors or cylinders.
comments.author: Mon257

comments.text:
It's in my home project; $$$$ are the main consideration. Ease of 
troubleshooting is pretty much last. How would manifolds help 
troubleshooting exactly?
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: That's cool!
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
+Mon257
Accually found a leaking cylinder with a thermo cam, the line to the 
cylinder was alot hotter then the rest so was almost glowing white on the 
camera. First and only time i had use of that camera..
comments.author: phogelbice

comments.text:
yes his right, theres no temp. difference on internal leaked cylinders due 
to worn piston seals. Internal leaked cylinders could only determine if a 
rod extend even the control valves are neutral or no command. Either way 
you could remove each work ports (A or B) to check if theres internal leak 
(off course safety first by lowering the load.
comments.author: Mon257

comments.text:
I doubt you'd see a temp difference with a leaking cylinder. There is a 
better way than opening all the cylinders, but it's too complicated to 
explain. I'll make a vid about it, OK?
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
probably i didnt explain my self correctly cos you didnt answer my 
question. how i use this thermometer? what the temp diffrence to understand 
theres a leakage? i will give you an example last week i had a grapple with 
5 hydraulic cylinder and the grapple close it self when he should stay 
static so i opend all of the piston and i saw there 2 of them leaking from 
inside the piston head, for next time how i can use this techniqe you show 
on video and avoid opening all of them and just the 2 3 4 that leaks? how i 
see it ? there suposse to be a diffrence in the temp?.
comments.author: ‫אחמד עאזם‬‎

comments.text:
A component that is bypassing internally is hotter than the other 
components in the system. It is an easy way to find a good starting point 
for diagnosis. This is just one technique and is no replacement for 
thorough reading and understanding of the manual and schematics. Cheers!
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: You cant say shmoo on you tube. Someone is gonna flag u.﻿
comments.author: ponkkaa

comments.text:
Seems like you were dealing with a pilot operated relief valve.  I do no 
know about the design ofthe valve in your video, but seems to have spool, 
bias spring, pilot/dart, load spring & tensioner. Just a comment about the 
pressure trapped in the cartridge. Since the valve/block assembly is 
disconnected from the system, there is no pressure in the load spring's 
chamber (the hole minute 3:37) since it drains to tank. Any backpressure on 
tank line is aditive to the valve seting for this reason. Some PORV's have 
the spring chamber vented indepdently. I hope my note is helpful.﻿
comments.author: cv111

comments.text:
Hi CV! 
Indeed, your note is helpful. I mainly wanted to be sure that there was no 
residual pressure, and so am careful even if I "know" that there is no 
pressure. 
But much more interestingly I think I am speaking to a hydraulic engineer. 
Rexroth? Sauer? Hydac? I very much appreciate your comments!
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: well done!﻿

comments.text:
I have a Bucky forklift about 1940 - 1950 any ideas where to find parts for 
the hydraulic cylinders?﻿
comments.author: James Matney

comments.text:
seals are like lego and so is the honed tubing and chrome rod. google 
hydraulic seals and micro honed tubing in your area. Tell the seal guys the 
pressure, OD, ID and thickness of seals, wear rings and wipers they'll hook 
you up.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
I thought a counterbalance valve has to over come a load before it will 
open? Is there anyway i could contact you privately email or something?? i 
have a rollback truck that has a few problems. Are you a hydraulics guy??﻿
comments.author: mrblonde108

comments.text:
be carefull with Counterbalance valves. you have Holding Pressure and 
Crack/Thermal Pressure. The second one is the pressure that the CB will 
open with no pressure in the pilot port. Never adjust a CB with lod on it.
comments.author: cv111

comments.text: sure you can PM me. not sure if I can help tho.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
"I thought a counterbalance valve has to over come a load before it will 
open?" exactly! The load it has to overcome is the oil on the opposite side 
of the piston that is forced out under pressure to open the counterbalance.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: is a counter balance pilot valve the same thing ??﻿
comments.author: mrblonde108

comments.text:
no. counter balance is completely different. It is also called a load check 
valve. One of it's uses is preventing a cylinder from moving unless the 
opposite direction has pressure on it too. It's a safety thing.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text: Thanks!  Great trick.  I'll be sharing this.﻿
comments.author: Alberto Knox

comments.text:
Thanks and agree with filter suggestion. Already got the parts, just 
haven't installed em.
Respectfully disagree with your RoT;  1hp per 1gpm @ 1000psi. Musn't 
neglect STICKtion.You'll  trip out trying to get that motor started under 
load if you size it for 1hp per 1gpm @ 1500psi. 
It would be v. dangerous to have your RV regulating the pressure. This is a 
constant duty cycle, not intermittent! The load on the hyd. motor is what 
is determining the sys. pres. During normal operation RV will be same temp 
as everything else. Only if there is a problem, hyd. motor jam, blocked 
DCV, will the RV get hot along with the other problem spot. 
Cheers!﻿
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
+AvE  Thank you! And no I do not trust my welding enough to bet my life on 
the weld.  Simple Steel structure, fine, pressure vessel and welding ss, I 
shall pass.
comments.author: Kimberly Peacock

comments.text:
Have you heard of the prime directive?
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.

To put your mind at ease, hit it with the temp gun during operation. If 
it's the same temp as everything else, you're golden.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
+Kimberly Peacock But to answer your question: Best Practice
Disassemble the cylinder, cut off the old one, clean up all the oil, no 
residue, no solvent fumes, weld on the new one, clean and re-assemble. You 
need to be a good welder to do this, cause, you know.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
+AvE I'm going to be running at half its rated flow and pressure, so I 
might get away with it, but I'm someone who likes to optimize all the 
components in a system. That said you are probably right. In this case it 
may not be worth the hassle.
comments.author: Kimberly Peacock

comments.text:
Ah, you didn't say that. Do you NEED to increase the port size, or do you 
think you'd like to? Sounds like a big hassle, best do a quick fluid 
velocity calc.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
+AvE The idea was to improve the flow, using an adapter won't remove the 
flow restriction.
comments.author: Kimberly Peacock

comments.text:
Nothing so complicated.  SAE 4 SAE 8 meaning NPT  1/4" to 1/2" or JIC -4 to 
-8 or ORFS( O-ring face)? Either way, just look in the fitting supply 
catalog and buy the adaptor.
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
I have a question for you. I want to enlarge the ports on my hydraulic 
cylinder from SAE 4 (1/4") to SAE 8 (1/2)  Thing is the ports are male, how 
would you go about enlarging them?  I suppose I could convert them to 
innies, but am afraid that might mess things up.  Maybe cut an SAE 8 male 
fitting, notch it and tap the hole, flush everything in the cylinder, and 
then weld the notched fitting?  Up to 2K PSI so don't want a surprise.
comments.author: Kimberly Peacock

comments.text:
Rule of thumb is 1hp to 1 gpm at 1500 psi. That electronic motor is more 
than enough to run that itty bitty gear pump. Your pump pressure is 
regulated by that relief valve regardless. I would suggest an inline 
pressure filter between your pump and valve. This would alleviate all 
future problems. ﻿
comments.author: A. Diaz

comments.text:
EDIT TO ADD: The relief valve you disassembled is regulating pressure to 
your mil.. It will always be hotter, even under normal working conditions, 
if you exceed 1500 psi.
comments.author: A. Diaz

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment! BUT nope, not Teflon; rocks. The white stuff is 
quartz gold ore. I use the loctite on pipe threads and teflon on air 
fittings. 18 years of hands-on troubleshooting all over the planet: never 
had a stitch of trouble with either. NPT fittings are horrible, but we're 
still stuck with 'em (cheap?). I'll heat up the female, gob on the dope and 
torque to FT. Poor bastard that has to take it apart (generally myself); 
but somethings just MUST NOT LEAK...
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
Ja, if emmissivity is an issue for sure, black tape or matte black paint. 
Good point, thanks for sharing!
comments.author: AvE

comments.text:
I believe that the "Schmooie" appeared to be Teflon (?). Teflon is bad for 
hydraulic systems, as your vid seems to show. The standard at our company 
is LOCTITE 545. No problems as long as the threads are clean - CLEAN (no 
oil or other contaminants). No Teflon, liquid or tape. Gums up the works. 
Again, Thank You for this very Important Lesson in Troubleshooting.
comments.author: toohip1959

comments.text:
Hey, GREAT Video!!! As a former Reliability Supervisor, may I suggest that 
you wrap Black Electricians tape (0.95) on any component that you use the 
I/R Gun on. This'll give the best temp reading and point the gun as close 
as possible (an inch or two). Else you may get surrounding average temp 
readings. Closer is better, nothing reflective, like galv, S.S. or shiny. 
We had to spray a coupling Flat Black, while running, to get a correct 
reading. Just info, nada mas. Great Vid! Thank You!
comments.author: toohip1959
